knee_oa_overview.title: Knee Osteoarthritis - OrthoBullets
knee_oa_overview.content:
Knee osteoarthritis (OA) is a degenerative joint disease characterized by progressive loss of articular cartilage. It is the most common form of arthritis affecting the knee.

Epidemiology:
- Prevalence increases with age, affecting >10% of adults over 60
- More common in women than men (ratio 1.5-2:1)
- Risk factors include age, obesity (BMI >30), prior knee injury, and genetic predisposition

Pathophysiology:
- Progressive cartilage degeneration with subchondral bone changes
- Osteophyte formation at joint margins
- Synovial inflammation and joint effusion
- Meniscal degeneration often coexists

Clinical Presentation:
- Gradual onset of pain, worse with weight-bearing and activity
- Morning stiffness lasting <30 minutes (distinguishes from inflammatory arthritis)
- Joint crepitus on movement
- Decreased range of motion
- Varus or valgus deformity in advanced cases

Diagnosis:
- Clinical criteria: Age >50, morning stiffness <30 min, crepitus, bony tenderness, bony enlargement
- Radiographic findings: Joint space narrowing, osteophytes, subchondral sclerosis, cysts
- Kellgren-Lawrence grading system (0-4)

Treatment:
- Conservative: Weight loss, physical therapy, NSAIDs, intra-articular injections
- Surgical: Arthroscopy (limited role), osteotomy, unicompartmental or total knee arthroplasty
key_points: Most common form of knee arthritis
Risk factors: age, obesity, prior injury
Morning stiffness <30 minutes differentiates from RA
Treatment ladder: conservative to surgical
knee_oa_overview.epidemiology: Affects >10% of adults over 60, female predominance
knee_oa_overview.pathoanatomy: Progressive cartilage loss with osteophyte formation
knee_oa_overview.diagnosis: Clinical: age >50, stiffness <30min, crepitus. Radiographic: joint space narrowing, osteophytes
knee_oa_overview.treatment: Weight loss, PT, NSAIDs, injections, surgery for refractory cases

acl_injury.title: ACL Injury - OrthoBullets
acl_injury.content:
Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury is one of the most common ligamentous injuries of the knee, particularly in athletes.

Epidemiology:
- Incidence: 200,000+ cases annually in US
- Female athletes 4-6x higher risk than males in same sports
- Most common in cutting/pivoting sports: soccer, basketball, skiing

Mechanism:
- Non-contact injury (70%): sudden deceleration, cutting, landing from jump
- Contact injury (30%): direct blow to lateral knee
- Combined injuries common (ACL + meniscus, ACL + MCL)

Clinical Presentation:
- Audible 'pop' at time of injury
- Immediate swelling (hemarthrosis within 2 hours)
- Giving way or instability sensation
- Difficulty weight-bearing initially

Physical Examination:
- Lachman test (most sensitive): positive anterior translation at 30 degrees flexion
- Anterior drawer test: anterior translation at 90 degrees flexion
- Pivot shift test (most specific): subluxation and reduction

Imaging:
- MRI: 95% sensitivity, 95% specificity
- Segond fracture on X-ray pathognomonic for ACL injury

Treatment:
- Non-operative: Physical therapy, bracing (for low-demand patients)
- Operative: ACL reconstruction with autograft or allograft
- Return to sport: 9-12 months post-reconstruction
key_points: Non-contact mechanism most common (70%)
Females 4-6x higher risk than males
Lachman test most sensitive, pivot shift most specific
MRI 95% sensitive and specific
acl_injury.epidemiology: 200,000+ cases/year in US, higher in female athletes
acl_injury.classification: Complete vs partial tear, associated injuries
acl_injury.diagnosis: Lachman test, pivot shift, MRI confirmation
acl_injury.treatment: PT + bracing or surgical reconstruction based on activity level

meniscus_tear.title: Meniscus Tear - OrthoBullets
meniscus_tear.content:
Meniscal tears are among the most common knee injuries, with treatment depending on tear pattern, location, and patient factors.

Anatomy:
- Medial and lateral menisci are C-shaped fibrocartilage structures
- Blood supply: peripheral 1/3 (red zone) has healing potential
- Central 2/3 (white zone) is avascular, poor healing

Epidemiology:
- Peak incidence in athletes 20-30 years (traumatic)
- Second peak in >40 years (degenerative)
- Medial meniscus tears more common than lateral

Mechanism:
- Traumatic: twisting injury on planted foot, often with ACL injury
- Degenerative: minimal trauma, associated with OA

Clinical Presentation:
- Joint line tenderness (medial or lateral)
- Mechanical symptoms: locking, catching, giving way
- Swelling (delayed, 12-24 hours)
- Pain with twisting or squatting

Physical Examination:
- McMurray test: click/pain with rotation during extension
- Thessaly test: rotation at 20 degrees flexion while standing
- Joint line tenderness

Imaging:
- MRI: 95% sensitivity for medial, 85% for lateral tears
- Grade 3 signal extending to articular surface indicates tear

Treatment:
- Conservative: PT, NSAIDs for degenerative tears
- Meniscectomy: For non-repairable tears
- Meniscal repair: For peripheral tears in young patients
key_points: Peripheral (red zone) tears can heal
Medial tears more common than lateral
McMurray and Thessaly tests for diagnosis
Repair preferred over meniscectomy when possible
meniscus_tear.diagnosis: Joint line tenderness, McMurray test, MRI
meniscus_tear.treatment: PT for degenerative; repair or meniscectomy for traumatic

patellofemoral_syndrome.title: Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome - OrthoBullets
patellofemoral_syndrome.content:
Patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS) is anterior knee pain arising from the patellofemoral joint, common in young active individuals.

Epidemiology:
- Most common cause of anterior knee pain
- Female:male ratio 2:1
- Peak in adolescents and young adults
- Common in runners, cyclists, jumpers

Etiology:
- Multifactorial: overuse, malalignment, muscle imbalance
- VMO weakness or dysplasia
- Tight lateral structures (ITB, lateral retinaculum)
- Training errors (rapid increase in activity)

Clinical Presentation:
- Anterior or peripatellar pain
- Worse with stairs, squatting, prolonged sitting ('theater sign')
- Occasional giving way (from pain inhibition, not instability)
- Crepitus with knee flexion

Physical Examination:
- Patellar grind test (J-sign)
- Q-angle measurement (>20 degrees abnormal)
- VMO assessment
- Hip abductor strength (Trendelenburg)

Treatment:
- First-line: Physical therapy (VMO strengthening, hip strengthening)
- Patellar taping or bracing
- Activity modification
- NSAIDs for acute flares
- Surgery rarely indicated (lateral release, realignment)
key_points: Most common cause of anterior knee pain
Theater sign: pain with prolonged sitting
VMO weakness and lateral structure tightness contribute
PT is first-line treatment, surgery rarely needed
patellofemoral_syndrome.epidemiology: Female predominance, peak in adolescents/young adults
patellofemoral_syndrome.diagnosis: Clinical: anterior pain, theater sign, patellar grind

septic_arthritis.title: Septic Arthritis of the Knee - OrthoBullets
septic_arthritis.content:
Septic arthritis is a joint infection that requires urgent diagnosis and treatment to prevent joint destruction.

Epidemiology:
- Incidence: 2-10 per 100,000 per year
- Risk factors: age >80, diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, prior joint surgery, immunosuppression
- Knee is the most commonly affected joint (50%)

Microbiology:
- Staphylococcus aureus: most common (40-50%)
- Streptococcus species: 20%
- Gram-negative bacilli: 15-20% (elderly, immunocompromised)
- Gonococcal: consider in sexually active young adults

Clinical Presentation:
- Acute onset of joint pain, swelling, warmth
- Fever (present in 60-80%)
- Inability to bear weight
- Limited range of motion due to pain

Diagnosis:
- Joint aspiration: WBC >50,000/mm3 (>90% PMNs)
- Gram stain positive in 50-75%
- Blood cultures positive in 50%
- Synovial fluid glucose <40 mg/dL

Treatment:
- Emergency surgical drainage (arthroscopic or open)
- IV antibiotics for 2-4 weeks
- Empiric: Vancomycin + third-generation cephalosporin
- Serial joint aspirations if needed
key_points: Medical emergency requiring urgent treatment
S. aureus most common pathogen
Joint WBC >50,000 with >90% PMNs diagnostic
Surgical drainage + IV antibiotics is standard
septic_arthritis.diagnosis: Joint aspiration WBC >50,000, Gram stain, cultures
